awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaborative Research: The Cenozoic radiation of eupolypod ferns: did selection for drought tolerance drive the evolutionary physiology of sporophytes and gametophytes?
awd_abstract_narration:
Seed-free vascular plants such as ferns are the second most diverse plant lineage after the flowering plants, yet given their two-stage lifecycle and apparent intolerance of drought, the bases of their continued success are not completely understood.  Recent studies have shown that both fern fronds (the vegetative generation) and fern gametophytes (the sexual generation) have evolved numerous strategies to cope with and recover from severe drought stress. This research investigates the water relations of both stages of the fern lifecycle to test the hypothesis that the evolution of traits typically related to drought tolerance promoted the expansion of ferns from largely moist, terrestrial habitats to drier, sunnier canopy habitats. The research will focus on drought tolerant traits of two recent fern lineages, which represent the bulk of tropical fern species diversity. Physiological, morphological and anatomical attributes will be examined across select species in the field and in the laboratory. This basic research will not only expand knowledge of the processes that shape biological diversity, but also potentially identify novel plant traits that could assist with the development of more drought resistant agricultural species. Students will receive international research experiences in Mexico and Costa Rica, and student/instructor exchanges will promote research collaboration. Outreach activities to the public will combine with non-profit collaborators at the Save the Redwood League and the Southern Madison Heritage Trust to illustrate the important role of ferns and other non-vascular plants in the ecology of natural plant communities. 

In order to determine whether drought stress exerts strong, convergent selection pressure on fern sporophytes and gametophytes, this research will examine the desiccation tolerance of gametophytes from numerous species in the Pteridaceae. The Pteridaceae are a hyper-diverse family of ferns that are ancestral to the Eupolypods, and the results from this study will complement an existing data set documenting drought tolerance in the Pteridaceae sporophytes. A second set of studies will examine the drought tolerance of epiphytic and terrestrial Eupolypod sporophytes. Experiments will test resistance to hydraulic failure by drought-induced air entry, leaf turgor loss points, and relate these data to numerous anatomical and morphological traits. Lastly, complementary studies looking at the desiccation tolerance of gametopytes in this group will be conducted. The results will be analyzed in a phylogenetic framework, which will explicitly test for correlated trait evolution in both sporophytes and gametophytes.

por.por_cntn:
Tropical forests have long been known to harbor immense botanical diversity. This is especially true of the rainforest canopy that is home to more diversity than any other habitat. Epiphytic ferns are notable components of the canopy often making up the majority of the richness and density of canopy vegetation. Yet, the life of an epiphytic fern species is very different from one growing on the forest floor. The epiphytic niche is often described as a liminal space that is dry, poor in nutrients, and exposed to high light levels: a set of conditions that one would not immediately associate with ferns. In spite of a fossil record that dates epiphytisim back to at least the Carboniferous, most modern species evolved during the well-known and rapid Cenozoic radiation of plants. Understanding how ferns, with small independent gametophytes that rely on water for fertilization, radiated from mesic, low-light, terrestrial understory ancestors into the canopy has long puzzled scientists. The goal of this project was to investigate the parallel role of sporophyte and gametophyte water relations in the evolution of ferns. The overarching hypothesis is that the evolution of ecophysiological traits associated with drought tolerance promoted the post-Cretaceous radiation of ferns. This basic research will not only inform our understanding of the processes that shape biological diversity, but also potentially identify novel plant traits that could help breeders develop more drought resistant plants. 

The funding for this project helped reveal many novel aspects of fern biology. We documented that the gametophytes of epiphytic species were more water stress tolerant than terrestrial species and that tolerance was more closely related to habitat and not phylogeny as was previously thought. In addition, we made the relatively shocking discovery that fern sperm could live for hours. This was contrary to dogma suggesting that spermatozoa lived for only minutes. While we were unable to link longevity with habit, epiphytic taxa typically produced longer-lived sperm. Such a discovery holds tremendous potential to transform our understanding of fern reproductive ecology and even challenges the concept of a population in this group. This project also represented the most expansive effort to date to examine sporophyte physiology. By examining nearly 40 taxa, we discovered that epiphytic fern sporophytes rely on drought avoidance over drought tolerance mechanisms. Again, a finding that deviated from earlier expectations. Overall, we discovered evidence of widespread parallel convergent evolution, albeit through different mechanisms, in gametophytes and sporophytes. Taken together, these results suggest that adaptations to water stress were some of the most important selective pressures acting on the radiation of ferns into the epiphytic niche.

The funding provided through this grant also had deep and significant broader impacts. Over the course of the funding timeframe, this project directly supported the senior theses of eight undergraduate students at Colgate University, five of which were minority women. It has also resulted in the publication of eight peer-reviewed scientific articles, four being coauthored with undergraduate students. The work also supported the presentation of three thesis projects at the Annual Meeting of the Botanical Society of America over three years and undergraduate student travel to field sites in Costa Rica. Three of these students have entered graduate school in STEM related fields and a fourth is studying education and plans to become a high school science teacher. The work has also helped transform Colgate’s biology curriculum by supporting the creation of a new fern lab for our introductory series. More importantly, it inspired the creation of an entirely new course, Bio 206: Organismal Biology – Ferns taught by one of the PI’s. 

To date, this project has generated important data that have altered the way we think about the functional ecology and evolution of ferns. Beyond this, the work offers insights into the evolution of early land plants and helps partially explain mechanisms behind adaptive radiation into the rainforest canopy. The work of this study will continue to enhance Colgate's curriculum and spread beyond as students entering our program carry the influence of this project with them.
